citations.narrative:
Medical records state that on the morning of December 31, 2024, Snapper, an adult female sea lion, vomited a piece of
foam that she likely ingested during the blood collection/catch performed the previous day. The foam piece was
approximately 2 inches by 2 inches in size and was traced back to the foam pad used in a medical procedure the previous
afternoon. No other pieces of the pad were determined to be missing. At approximately 2 pm on December 30, 2024,
Snapper was placed in a squeeze cage as part of a medical procedure. As the cage is tightened around the animal, they
will sometimes begin to strike out and mouth or bite at its surroundings. A foam pad is placed along the sides and front of
the cage to help position the animal and to help prevent the animal from injuring itself or its teeth on the metal bars of the
cage. During the procedure, Snapper began to mouth and bite at her surroundings. It is believed that this is when she
inadvertently bit off and ingested a piece of the foam pad in front of her.
Ingesting foreign material can cause the animal to experience discomfort, stress, and possible injury.
Handling of all animals shall be done as expeditiously and carefully as possible in a manner that does not cause trauma,
overheating, excessive cooling, behavioral stress, physical harm, or unnecessary discomfort. To be corrected by the next
re-license inspection.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by March 31, 2025, or the applicant will forfeit the license fee
and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
Additional Inspectors:
KRISTIN NAPOLI, SUPERVISORY ANIMAL CARE SPECIALIST n

narrative:
2.131(b)(1)  Repeat
   
Handling of animals. 
Medical records state that on the morning of December 31, 2024, Snapper, an adult female sea lion, vomited a piece of 
foam that she likely ingested during the blood collection/catch performed the previous day. The foam piece was 
approximately 2 inches by 2 inches in size and was traced back to the foam pad used in a medical procedure the previous 
afternoon. No other pieces of the pad were determined to be missing. At approximately 2 pm on December 30, 2024, 
Snapper was placed in a squeeze cage as part of a medical procedure. As the cage is tightened around the animal, they 
will sometimes begin to strike out and mouth or bite at its surroundings. A foam pad is placed along the sides and front of 
the cage to help position the animal and to help prevent the animal from injuring itself or its teeth on the metal bars of the 
cage. During the procedure, Snapper began to mouth and bite at her surroundings. It is believed that this is when she 
inadvertently bit off and ingested a piece of the foam pad in front of her. 
 
Ingesting foreign material can cause the animal to experience discomfort, stress, and possible injury. 
 
Handling of all animals shall be done as expeditiously and carefully as possible in a manner that does not cause trauma, 
overheating, excessive cooling, behavioral stress, physical harm, or unnecessary discomfort. To be corrected by the next 
re-license inspection. 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by March 31, 2025, or the applicant will forfeit the license fee 
and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.

Additional Inspectors: 
KRISTIN NAPOLI, SUPERVISORY ANIMAL CARE SPECIALIST n
